article.description: Alonzo Mourning had 21 points and 12 rebounds as the Miami Heat snapped a 12-game losing streak -- the longest of coach Pat riley's career --  with a 98-94 overtime victory over the Seattle SuperSonics on Friday night.
article.headline: Heat earn franchise's first victory in Seattle

images.name: Grant, Brian 011207 inline
images.caption: Brian Grant kneels in relief as the weight of losing 12 straight leaves his shoulders.

article.linkText: Heat finally figure it out, beat Sonics to end 12-game skid
article.story:
SEATTLE (AP) -- With the longest losing streak of his coaching career finally over, Pat Riley didn't see much reason to celebrate. The Heat snapped a 12-game losing streak with a 98-94 overtime victory over the Seattle SuperSonics on Friday. "We were very fortunate to be able to get off the slide," Riley said. "Our execution was lacking in the last four minutes of the game. We were just forcing things in a desperate manner. That's what has gotten us in trouble, and it just about got us beat again tonight." Jim Jackson's 14-foot jumper at the buzzer sent the game into overtime tied 88-88. Miami took charge early in the extra period as Seattle missed its first eight shots. The Heat had a 96-90 lead with 25 seconds left. Gary Payton made a layup with 18 seconds left, and Vladimir Radmanovic's uncontested driving layup eight seconds later cut Miami's lead to three at 97-94. Jones hit one of two free throws, and Payton missed a layup as time expired for the final margin. "We'll take it, but we can't be satisfied with our end-of-game execution," Riley said. Alonzo Mourning led the Heat (3-14) with 21 points, 12 rebounds and five blocked shots. Jones added 17 points for the Heat, and Brian Grant had 15 points and 10 rebounds. Payton narrowly missed his second consecutive triple-double with 25 points, 11 assists and nine rebounds. Rashard Lewis added 22 points and 11 rebounds and Brent Barry had 18 points. Miami's last victory also had come in overtime against Seattle -- 87-85 on Nov. 6. "We just haven't been able to get over the hump because of poor rebounding, poor execution, not closing out in the fourth quarter," Grant said. "Tonight it went the other way." "We've been falling apart late in the game on defense," Jones said. "We did it again tonight, but we stayed with it and we got the win." Miami's mistakes kept the game close late in regulation. Payton hit a 20-foot jumper with 36 seconds left in the fourth to put Seattle up 87-86, after Rod Strickland threw a pass out of bounds from the top of the key with no defensive pressure on him. Rashard Lewis put Seattle up 88-86 with 9 seconds left by hitting one of two free throws after being fouled by LaPhonso Ellis. The Sonics had gained possession after Jones collided with Heat teammate Anthony Carter on a drive, forcing a turnover. "Jimmy hit that shot to keep us in it," Mourning said. "Things could have easily gone the other way." The Sonics had trailed until Barry's 3-pointer at the third-quarter buzzer put them up 69-68. Neither team led by more than five points in the fourth. The Heat avoided tying the second-worst skid in franchise history. Their only worse losing streaks were 13 games during the 1989-90 season and an 0-17 start to their inaugural 1988-89 season. The Sonics (9-13), who have lost five of their last six games, had to go with a small lineup because of foul trouble. Power forward Vin Baker fouled out with 2:51 left in the game. Starting center Calvin Booth sat on the bench after getting three fouls in the first half, and backup center Art Long and Lewis both had five fouls. "We played a lot of small ball, and we didn't shoot the ball particularly well all game long," Seattle guard Brent Barry said. "I thought we ran out of gas," Sonics coach Nate McMillan said. "We had some open looks at the end, but you know, we had three guys play 46, 47 and 47 minutes because of foul trouble." The Heat led 49-42 at the half, as Mourning had 15 points on 5-for-6 shooting and Jones had 14. Payton led Seattle with 13.

Game notes
Miami came in with losses in all six of its road games, including an 87-83 loss to the Los Angeles Clippers on Tuesday. The Heat had lost their previous 13 games in Seattle. ... McMillan said swingman Desmond Mason, who was put on the injured list Tuesday with a sprained right knee, continues to walk with a limp but may practice with the team next week. Meanwhile, reserve center Jerome James, out with a sprained right foot, also may return to practice. ... Kendall Gill remains out for Miami with a fractured right pinky finger.

statistics.name: points
statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.name: fieldGoals
statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.name: freeThrows
statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).
